title: 114_hr2324
content: The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" allows for special conveyance authority regarding small parcels of national forest system land and public lands. The "Small Lands Tracts Conveyance Act" defines key terms like "adjacent landholder," "Director concerned," and "eligible Federal lands parcel" as part of the special conveyance authority for small parcels of National Forest System land and public lands. The "Federal lands parcel" is a parcel of National Forest System land or public lands that meets specific criteria, including being adjacent to non-Federal land, located within a populated area, not subject to existing rights, lacking exceptional resources, and not habitat for endangered species. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 defines an "exceptional resource" as a valuable resource on public lands requiring extraordinary conservation for the benefit of the public. The term "Indian tribe" is defined in the Federally Recognized Indian Tribe List Act of 1994. The term "National Forest System land" is defined as land within the National Forest System, excluding certain designated areas managed by the Forest Service. The term "public lands" excludes land managed by the Forest Service included in various designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. The term "public lands" in the United States excludes Bureau of Land Management-managed lands in designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. The term "public lands" in the United States excludes certain designated areas like national monuments, wilderness areas, and national scenic areas. Regional Forester concerned refers to the Regional Forester with jurisdiction over National Forest System land in a specific Forest Service Region. Selection of eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance under this section is done by the Director or Regional Forester concerned in response to a request. The Director or Regional Forester selects eligible Federal lands parcels for conveyance in response to requests from adjacent landholders or recommendations from the Bureau of Land Management or National Forest System. Adjacent landholders can request to purchase parcels through a process created by the Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior. Guidelines are established for this process. The Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior will create a process for adjacent landholders to request to purchase eligible Federal lands parcels. The process will be consistent with other public purchase request processes used by the Forest Service and the Bureau of Land Management. It will be open to the public, available on the internet, and must be accessible within 90 days of the enactment of this Act. The process for adjacent landholders to request purchase of eligible Federal lands parcels must be available to the public within 90 days of the Act's enactment. The Director or Regional Forester will review the request and determine if the parcel meets the criteria within 30 days. If the request is rejected, the Director or Regional Forester will determine which portion of the parcel does not qualify. The Director or Regional Forester will provide a written explanation to the landowner if their request to purchase adjacent Federal lands is rejected, specifying the reasons for the rejection and which criteria the parcel failed to meet. The Director or Regional Forester will provide a written explanation to the landowner if their request to purchase adjacent Federal lands is rejected, specifying the reasons for the rejection and which criteria the parcel failed to meet. The rejected parcel must demonstrate why it fails to satisfy certain elements, the impact of continued administration by the Bureau of Land Management or Forest Service on the economy, and why the Federal Government should maintain ownership as the best steward. An appeal process is available for rejections. Parcel conveyed cannot exceed 160 acres unless a request is made. An eligible Federal lands parcel conveyed under this section may not exceed 160 acres unless approved by the Director or Regional Forester. An adjacent landholder can acquire one parcel per year, with the option for additional parcels if each is under 160 acres, subject to approval for more acreage. Federal lands parcels can be acquired up to 160 acres unless approved by the Director or Regional Forester. Public notice is required for available parcels, even if they share a boundary with a single non-Federal land parcel. The Director or Regional Forester must provide public notice for eligible Federal lands parcels that meet the criteria for conveyance. If the parcel shares a boundary with a single non-Federal land parcel, a negotiated sale will be conducted with the adjacent landholder. For parcels bordering multiple non-Federal land parcels owned by different adjacent landholders, competitive bidding procedures will be used for the sale. The sale of eligible public lands parcels must be conducted using competitive bidding procedures. The Director or Regional Forester may reject offers that do not meet the minimum consideration required. The purchaser of the parcel must comply with local planning and zoning regulations. (e) Compliance with local planning and zoning is required for the conveyance of eligible public lands parcels. The purchaser must agree to adhere to local land use ordinances and zoning plans. When selling eligible Federal lands parcels, the Director or Regional Forester will transfer all rights to the parcel via quitclaim deed, including the mineral estate. An appeals process is available if the Director or Regional Forester rejects an adjacent landholder. The appeals process is available if the Director or Regional Forester rejects an adjacent landholder's request for selection or purchase of a parcel of National Forest System land or public lands. An expedited Forest Service appeals process can be used for reconsideration of the rejection. The appeals process for reconsideration of a rejection of a land selection or purchase request can be done using the expedited Forest Service appeals process. The Director or Regional Forester will require a cash payment equal to the fair market value of the parcel for the sale of eligible Federal lands. The Director or Regional Forester will require a cash payment equal to the fair market value of an eligible Federal lands parcel being conveyed, established through an appraisal process. The Director or Regional Forester will conduct another appraisal if the initial one is rejected, following regulations. Proceeds from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands will be collected and distributed through a special Treasury fund. Funds collected from the conveyance of eligible Federal lands will be deposited into a Treasury fund. These funds will be distributed annually to States where the Federal Government owns more than 33% of the land area. Distribution will be based on a calculation where 50% goes to the State of conveyance and the remaining 50% is divided equally among other identified States. The conveyance funds from eligible Federal lands will be distributed to States based on ownership percentages. 50% goes to the State of conveyance, and the remaining 50% is divided equally among other identified States. States must use the funds for purchasing additional eligible Federal lands and complying with Federal requirements like the Endangered Species Act. The Director or Regional Forester will require the purchaser to cover costs for conveyance, including survey, appraisal, environmental documentation, and compliance with federal requirements like the Endangered Species Act. The Director or Regional Forester will require the purchaser to cover costs for conveyance, including survey, appraisal, environmental documentation, and administrative costs. Any excess amount collected in advance will be refunded to the purchaser. Amounts received as reimbursement will be credited to the fund. The Director or Regional Forester will refund any excess amount collected in advance for conveyance costs to the purchaser. Amounts received as reimbursement will be credited to the fund or account used for covering those costs, merging with existing amounts for the same purposes and conditions. Congress intends that the conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels should not exceed 18 months. The conveyance of eligible Federal lands parcels should not exceed 18 months and is categorically excluded from environmental assessment requirements. This conveyance authority is in addition to existing sale authority under the Federal Land Policy and Management Act.
